title: How to avoid repetition in writing - Quora

response.answer_text: Variation. Variation with words, sentence structure, length, and paragraph structure. It’s honestly a lot easier than it seems. Make sure that your sentences aren’t all the same length; and make sure there is variation is paragraph length as well. This makes the page visually interesting, and shakes everything up. This makes it easier to digest, and easier to read. Variation with words is also a pretty simple thing to fix. Thesaurus.com - The world's favorite online thesaurus! will save your life, I promise. Make sure you’re not using the same word in every sentence, and paragraph. “Said,” is one of the most obvious examples. If you’re constantly using the word, “said,” things are going to get a little monotonous. Even switching to, “spoke,” can help. But make sure you’re not only using those two words. Get descriptive. Instead of “said,” if your character is angry, use “growled,” or if they are sad, perhaps “wept,” or “cried” is better. If you want to get rid of repetition, then shake things up. Variation will be your best tool.

If you’re using MS Word - try running a search on some words you visually see repeated when you self-edit, but also run a search on common junk or bloat words - big culprits are the following: “that” and “just” which shows up more via dialog or right before a dialog tag, but also “been” and “had” which is frequent in narrative. Some others are: pretty much, really, probably, seriously, and suddenly- you can find them on Word by entering in “ly” and it will highlight every egregious adverb in your writing - it was also reveal which of those are your subconscious “habit” words you’re prone to repeating without even realizing it. I was appalled when I saw how many times my character said “really”, for instance - when using Word’s “find” function to weed trim the bloat. You can look online for frequent repetitious words, a nd you can also use grammar software, such as Grammarly or Autocrit - a trial version of either one will be enough to get you started on how to create a search/find on Word to break your repetition habit. Keep a dictionary handy (or use one online) so you can swap out repeated words.
